algorithms.imageProcessing.features

Class HCPT

  • java.lang.Object
    • algorithms.imageProcessing.features.HCPT

  • public class HCPT
extends java.lang.Object
    A class holding histograms of a polar theta color space greyscale image and methods to extract features. The algorithm is similar to those mentioned in HOGs.java except that the histograms below have bins of color space and the added units are "1" unit of the pixel color. TODO: The differencing methods also take into account wrap around for the axis.
    Author:
    nichole

      • intersection

        public float intersection(int[] histA,
                          int[] histB)
        calculate the intersection of histA and histB which have already been normalized to the same scale. A result of 0 is maximally dissimilar and a result of 1 is maximally similar. The orientations are needed to compare the correct rotated bins to one another. Internally, orientation of 90 leads to no shift for rotation, and orientation near 0 results in rotation of nBins/2, etc... Note that an orientation of 90 is a unit vector from x,y=0,0 to x,y=0,1.
        Parameters:
        histA -
        histB -
        Returns:

      • diff

        public float[] diff(int[] histA,
                    int[] histB)
        CAVEAT: small amount of testing done, not yet throughly tested. calculate the intersection of histA and histB which have already been normalized to the same scale. A result of 0 is maximally dissimilar and a result of 1 is maximally similar. The orientations are needed to compare the correct rotated bins to one another. Internally, orientation of 90 leads to no shift for rotation, and orientation near 0 results in rotation of nBins/2, etc... Note that an orientation of 90 is a unit vector from x,y=0,0 to x,y=0,1.
        Parameters:
        histA -
        histB -
        Returns:

      • diffOfFeatures

        public float[] diffOfFeatures(int[] featureA,
                              int[] featureB)
        CAVEAT: small amount of testing done, not yet throughly tested. calculate the difference of histA and histB which have already been normalized to the same scale. A result of 0 is maximally dissimilar and a result of 1 is maximally similar. Note that because the feature contains spatially ordered concatenation of histograms, the registration of featureA and featureB to the same orientation must be done before this method (more specifically, before extraction to features). *
        Parameters:
        featureA -
        featureB -
        Returns:
